ns0:Rule.ns0:title: CGROUP_DAEMON in sysconfig scripts
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module searches for the CGROUP_DAEMON variable in the files in the /etc/sysconfig/ directory.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
In Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6, the CGROUP_DAEMON option can be used in any of the files in the /etc/sysconfig/ directory to specify a list of control groups that the daemon will be run in. For example, CGROUP_DAEMON="cpu:daemons cpuacct:/" will run it in the daemons group for the CPU controller, and in the '/' group for the CPU accounting controller.
We cannot automatically port this to systemd-based Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7. For more information, see https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux/7/html-single/Resource_Management_Guide/index.html.

ns0:Group.ns0:title: Checking the system version and variant

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Checking the system version and variant
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks if the system is the latest released version and a supported variant for the upgrade to be successful.

ns0:Group.ns0:title: Consequences of upgrading to RHEL 7.6 instead of the latest RHEL minor version

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Consequences of upgrading to RHEL 7.6 instead of the latest RHEL minor version
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The default system setup after the upgrade to RHEL 7.6 is to receive latest RHEL 7 updates - using `yum update` then updates the system to RHEL 7.7 or any later RHEL 7 minor version. The RHEL 7 to RHEL 8 upgrade tooling however allows upgrades from RHEL 7.6 to RHEL 8 only.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
The Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 in-place upgrade utilities, namely the Preupgrade Assistant and the Red Hat Upgrade Tool, will continue to provide a pathway to upgrade to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.6. The benefit of using Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.6 as a target version is that it allows us to provide an automated upgrade experience to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8 through the in-place upgrade tooling.
Here are the recommended configurations:
1) If you plan to upgrade to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8 or stay on Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.6, after upgrading to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7:
- run `subscription-manager release --set 7.6`
- enable the Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 Extended Update Support (EUS) repositories to receive latest updates for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.6
2) If yo do not plan to upgrade to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8 or stay on Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.6, after upgrading to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7:
- leave the release unset (the default) and receive content for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.7 or any later minor version from yum
- running `yum update` will allow you to update the system to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.7 or any later minor version
Note: An automated upgrade path from Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8 will not be enabled from each Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 minor version. The current plan is to support an automated upgrade from Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.6 to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8 and from the last Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 minor version that Red Hat releases.
For the latest information about upgrades of Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8, please refer to:
https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/8/html/upgrading_to_rhel_8/index.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: AIDE
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The AIDE tool is used for "guarding" the system integrity. The module detects if AIDE is installed and being used.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext: After the upgrade, type 'aide --update' to update the AIDE tool.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: CA bundles
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: Later versions of Red Hat Enterprise Linux include a shared store for certificate authorities. The module informs that any additional trusted certificate authorities must be placed in a new location, and that you should not modify the distributed certificate authority bundles. The Preupgrade Assistant cannot automatically identify how certificate bundles have been modified on your system.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 includes a shared store for certificate authorities.
You can find more information about this shared store by reading the
following man page on a Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.x system:
$ man update-ca-trust
In previous versions of Red Hat Enterprise Linux, modifying the distributed certificate bundles
(such as the /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.trust.crt file) was a way of adding
an additional trusted certificate authority to the system.
These additional trusted certificate authorities must be ported forward to
the Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 system manually. Place them as certificate (PEM or DER)
files to the /etc/pki/ca-trust/source/anchors/ directory, and then type:
# update-ca-trust

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Red Hat Developer Toolset
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks if the Red Hat Developer Toolset packages are installed.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
Perform the following steps to upgrade from Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7:
1) Uninstall all Red Hat Developer Toolset packages.
2) Upgrade the system.
3) Check if the Red Hat Developer Toolset repo exists, and if not, install it via channels.
4) Install your Developer Toolset packages again.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: GRUB to GRUB 2 migration
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module informs about a need to migrate GRUB to GRUB 2 manually, and it backs up the splash.xpm.gz file if necessary.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
GRUB is used as a loader of the Linux system. However, Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 does not include GRUB anymore. Instead, it includes GRUB 2 only. Because the configuration system has been completely overhauled, it is not possible to migrate the GRUB setup to GRUB 2 automatically.
During the upgrade process, GRUB will be preserved in the Master Boot Record, and a temporary GRUB configuration will be deployed, so that you can boot into the upgraded system.
Because it is not possible to support the temporary configuration, you need to rewrite it, and install GRUB 2 to the Master Boot Record manually after the upgrade.
For details about GRUB 2, see the "System Administrator's Guide" at https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux/7/html/System_Administrators_Guide/ch-Working_with_the_GRUB_2_Boot_Loader.html.
It is strongly recommended to back up the grub-legacy package manually before the upgrade. You can find more information about backing up the package and upgrading from GRUB to GRUB 2 at https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux/7/html/System_Administrators_Guide/sec-Upgrading_from_GRUB_Legacy_to_GRUB_2.html.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Grubby
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: A workaround to prevent crashing of the grubby utility. The module fills initrd into the /boot/grub/grub.conf file by the postupgrade script.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext: The module works around crashing grubby. It modifies the /boot/grub/grub.conf file by adding initrd.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Obsoleting Hardware Abstraction Layer
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks for packages dependent on HAL.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext: Hardware Abstraction Layer (HAL) is obsoleted, but not provided, by systemd. Migrate the applications dependent on HAL to udev/systemd.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Hyper-V
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks if the system runs on Hyper-V.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext: The in-place upgrade to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 as a guest on Hyper-V is not supported.

ns0:Group.ns0:title: Enabled and disabled services in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Enabled and disabled services in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks what services are enabled or disabled on the source system, and it also checks if the services are enabled or disabled in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
The module detects and lists the services that are disabled by default in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.
On the target system, the SysV init system is replaced by the systemd service manager. You can still use your current init scripts on the target system as they are internally wrapped and executed by systemd. However, in case you want to migrate your init scripts to unit files thoroughly, you have to do that manually. See https://access.redhat.com/solutions/912263 for more information.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Ethernet interface naming
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks if network interface names set through the /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-* files are compatible with device naming in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 still offers a possibility to specify names for network interface by setting the DEVICE and HWADDR options in the /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-* configuration files. Unfortunatelly, udev does not support swapping interface names anymore. In the case that you set ethX names to multiple network card, and kernel discovers them in a different order, udev rule 60-net.rules will most likely fail.
It is highly recommended to rename such interfaces or remove the DEVICE line from the ifcfg configuration files.
Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 also introduces predictable network interface device names. For more information, see http://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/systemd/PredictableNetworkInterfaceNames/.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: The /etc/rc.local and /etc/rc.d/rc.local files
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks if the user modified the /etc/rc.local and /etc/rc.d/rc.local files.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
It is highly advisable to create your own systemd services or udev rules to run scripts after boot instead of using this file.
In contrast to previous versions, this script will not be run after all the other services due to the parallel execution during the boot process.
Enter the 'chmod +x /etc/rc.d/rc.local' command to ensure that this script will be run during boot.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Java upgrade
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module looks for possible troubles with the upgrade of Java and it informs about them.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext: * OpenJDK 8 is installed. The configuration files will be backed up, and then they will be restored by the post-upgrade script automatically.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: java-1.8.0-ibm compatibility check
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks for incompatibility between java-1.8.0-ibm package in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 and same package in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: The kernel-kdump package
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks for invalid /etc/zipl.conf records on the IBM z Systems architecture.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
There is a bug in the installation program of Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6, which results in one or more
invalid records added to the /etc/zipl.conf file if the kernel-kdump package was a part of the
initial installation. If these invalid records persist, the system might not
be able to boot into Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.
Review the zipl.conf file and remove the invalid
records manually. Otherwise, redhat-upgrade-tool will attempt to remove
them.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: The cgroups configuration compatibility
ns0:Rule.ns0:description:
The module checks the libcgroup configuration files.
File(s) affected:
/etc/cgconfig.conf
/etc/cgrules.conf
/etc/cgconfig.d
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
In previous versions of Red Hat Enterprise Linux, system administrators built
custom cgroup hierarchies with the use of the cgconfig command from the libcgroup
package. This package is now deprecated.
Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 moves the resource management settings from the
process level to the application level by binding the cgroup hierarchy
with the systemd unit hierarchy. Therefore, you can manage the cgroup tree
with systemctl commands.
For more details, see the "Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 Resource Management Guide":
- Chapter 2 (Using Control Groups):
https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux/7/html/Resource_Management_Guide/chap-Using_Control_Groups.html
- Chapter 3 (Using libcgroup Tools):
https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux/7/html/Resource_Management_Guide/chap-Using_libcgroup_Tools.html

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Pluggable authentication modules (PAM)
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks for no longer supported PAMs.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
Pluggable authentication modules (PAM) are the core of the user authentication in any modern Linux distribution.
The pam_passwdqc and pam_ecryptfs modules were removed between Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 and Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7, which made some PAM configuration files no longer valid.
The Preupgrade Assistant comments out these modules in your PAM configuration
files after the in-place upgrade automatically, but review and
regain the authentication functionality in a different way, if these modules were
required for your authentication policy.

ns0:Group.ns0:title: Perl modules not distributed by Red Hat

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Perl modules not distributed by Red Hat
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module looks for Perl modules not distributed by Red Hat that need to be checked for the correct functionality with a newer Perl version in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
Perl was updated from version 5.10 to version 5.16. Read the Perl
section in the "Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 Developer Guide" for more details:
https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux/7/html/Developer_Guide/lib.details.html#libraries.perl

ns0:Group.ns0:title: PHP modules not distributed by Red Hat

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: PHP modules not distributed by Red Hat
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module looks for PHP modules not distributed by Red Hat that need to be checked for the correct functionality with a later PHP version in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
PHP was updated from version 5.3 to version 5.4.
For more details, see the upstream migration guide at
http://php.net/manual/en/migration54.php
The /etc/php.ini configuration file has been modified.
The /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf configuration file has been modified.
The following PHP module files are either not handled by any package or not signed by Red Hat:
/usr/lib64/php/modules/oci8.so

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: PolicyKit
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module informs about the necessity of checking modified or your own configuration files due to important changes in the PolicyKit configuration files.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
PolicyKit (alias polkit) does not use the *.conf and *.pkla files anymore. Everything is inside the
*.rules files instead, which contain rules written in JavaScript. See more in the
"Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 Desktop Migration and Administration Guide", Chapter 4, at
https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux/7/html/Desktop_Migration_and_Administration_Guide/policykit.html

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Python packages
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module provides you with a list of packages that need to be rebuilt for version 2.7.5 of the Python programming language, which is included in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 contains Python version 2.7.5. For more information about the differences from earlier versions and for further details, see https://access.redhat.com/site/articles/676453.
The files and directories listed below are not owned by any RPM packages, or they are owned by RPM packages that are not signed by Red Hat. These packages need to be rebuilt and reinstalled to work with Python 2.7.5.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Repositories for Kickstart
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks for enabled repositories and stores them in the /root/preupgrade/kickstart/available-repos file. They are later used for generating Kickstart.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
The module stores enabled repositories for Kickstart issues in the ./kickstart/available-repos file.
During the generation of Kickstart, these repositories are added to the Kickstart script.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: System requirements
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks if the system complies with the minimal requirements.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
/usr:
(only for migration process)

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Ruby 2.0.0
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module provides you with a list of packages that need to be rebuilt for version 2.0.0 of the Ruby programming language, which is used in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 contains Ruby version 2.0.0. The system paths for libraries and gems have changed from Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6.
The files and directories listed below are not owned by any RPM package, or they are owned by RPM packages that are not signed by Red Hat. These packages need to be rebuilt and reinstalled to work with Ruby 2.0.0.
For the information about migrating Ruby from Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7, see https://access.redhat.com/site/articles/790123.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Red Hat Software Collections (RHSCL)
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks if any RHSCL are installed.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
Perform the following steps to upgrade from Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7:
1) Uninstall all Red Hat Software Collections packages.
2) Upgrade the system.
3) Update the Red Hat Software Collections repository.
4) Install your collections again.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Red Hat Network Classic unsupported
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks if this system is registered with the Red Hat Network Classic.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
Red Hat Network Classic is not supported in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7. If your system is registered with RHN Classic, migrate to Certificate-based Red Hat Network.
See the instructions on how to migrate from RHN Classic to Certificate-based Red Hat Network using Red Hat Subscription Manager at https://access.redhat.com/site/solutions/129723.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Red Hat Subscription Manager
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module adds a new option 'full_refresh_on_yum' to the configuration file, if it is not there already. Also, unsets the release with subscription-manager.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext: If you see this, the check script probably failed to install the post-upgrade script.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Copying Kickstart
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module copies system Kickstart from the /root/ directory to the directory with results.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext: The module copies Kickstart generated by anaconda after the system installation. The /root/anaconda.cfg file is copied to the /root/preupgrade/kickstart/ directory, and the file is used by preupg-kickstart-generator for creating the preupgrade.ks file.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: The 'tuned' profiles
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks for the custom 'tuned' profiles on the system, and it stores them to the postupgrade directory.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
The module stores the custom 'tuned' profiles, which are located in the /etc/tune-profiles/ directory, to POSTUPGRADE_DIR.
After the upgrade to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7, the profiles can be migrated manually with the help of the 'tuned-man' and 'tuned-profiles' commands to the /etc/tuned/ directory.
For more information about 'tuned', see http://docs.fedoraproject.org/en-US/Fedora/20/html/Power_Management_Guide/tuned.html.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: UEFI boot loader
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks for EFI and it forbids an in-place upgrade when the EFI boot loader is present.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext: This system does not use the EFI boot loader. The Preupgrade Assistant will not replace your current boot loader automatically as it is too dangerous. If you want to use GRUB 2, do it manually after the upgrade by using 'grub2-install' and 'grub2-mkconfig'.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Yaboot
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module informs about the necessity of migrating Yaboot to GRUB 2.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
The module is valid only on the 64-bit PowerPC architecture and it checks if Yaboot is installed.
Yaboot cannot boot the Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 system. The Red Hat Upgrade Tool will install GRUB 2 during the upgrade. Create the /etc/default/grub file before running 'redhat-upgrade-tool' to ensure the correct GRUB 2 configuration. A misconfiguration might make the system unbootable.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: The yum configuration file
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks the yum configuration file.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
In Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7, the functionality of the yum-plugin-security package is a part of yum core.
After the upgrade, it will be impossible to undo, redo, or rollback to pre-upgrade yum transactions. Type 'yum history new' after the upgrade to start a new history file.
The way yum groups work has changed in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7. By default, yum treats groups as objects now. See the documentation for more information.

ns0:Group.ns0:title: Dangerous ranges of UIDs and GIDs

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Dangerous ranges of UIDs and GIDs
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks for IDs in the range 0 - 199 that are used without reservations, and it also checks for IDs that need to be moved from the range 500 - 999 before the migration.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
In Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6, the range reserved for system account IDs is 0 - 499, while in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 it is 0 - 999. This difference might cause troubles during the upgrade. In addition, the range 0 - 199 is prohibited from the use without a static ID reservation in the setup package. The IDs that are in this range might be reserved and used later by a package, and using them might cause the malfunction of the package.
The following problems were found on your system:
Your system contains UIDs or GIDs in the range 500 - 999. Therefore, the Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 defaults (system accounts limit on ID 499) will be kept to prevent mixing up the system and user accounts. If you can migrate your user accounts above 1000 easily, do so, and adjust the /etc/login.defs file to the values used in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.

ns0:Group.ns0:title: Incorrect usage of reserved UIDs and GIDs

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: Incorrect usage of reserved UIDs and GIDs
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks for changes in the reserved user and group IDs between Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 and Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7. In some cases, these changes might cause the unfunctionality of the system after the upgrade. This check mitigates the risks.
ns0:Rule.ns0:fixtext:
The packages might create system accounts with static IDs based on the reservation in the /usr/share/doc/setup-*/uidgid file. If you have any violations against the uidgid file reservation, the applications might not work properly, or they might cause some unexpected behavior. As the reservations between different releases of Red Hat Enterprise Linux might differ, check the results below carefully.
Especially the cases when an ID reserved by an application is used by a different account are really important. Using a different account than the reserved one might cause interoperability issues.
Invalid GID is used for the games account. Now, it is 100, but it should be 20.
This might cause troubles when an exact static GID is expected by an application.
The ID 6 reserved for the amandabackup account is used by disk.
The amandabackup account is expected to be created by the amanda package(s). If you plan to use the package(s) on the system, it might cause troubles as the amandabackup account might not be created properly.
Invalid UID is used for the tomcat account. Now, it is 501, but it should be 53.
This might cause troubles when an exact static UID is expected by an application.
Invalid GID is used for the tomcat account. Now, it is 99, but it should be 53.
This might cause troubles when an exact static GID is expected by an application.
These issues do not usually cause critical failures, but in rare cases they might contribute to some hard-to-analyze failures in the case where the system ID values are hard-coded in the application.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: The libuser.conf file
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks for a rejected configuration in the /etc/libuser.conf file. The rejected configuration is the combination of the ldap module with others, due to the ambiguity in password handling.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: NIS ypbind
ns0:Rule.ns0:description:
The module backs up the NIS ypbind configuration files.
File(s) affected:
/etc/yp.conf
/etc/sysconfig/ypbind

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: NIS Makefile
ns0:Rule.ns0:description:
The module backs up the NIS Makefile for generating maps.
File(s) affected:
/var/yp/Makefile

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: NIS server maps
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module informs about the need to re-generate the NIS server maps, because a different back-end format is used for caching them in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.

ns0:Group.ns0:title: NIS server UID_MIN and GID_MIN limits

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: NIS server UID_MIN and GID_MIN limits
ns0:Rule.ns0:description: The module checks if the users managed by NIS ypserv use UIDs or GIDs in the range 500 - 999, as this might cause complications after the upgrade.

ns0:Rule.ns0:title: The NIS server configuration file
ns0:Rule.ns0:description:
The module backs up the NIS ypserv and yppasswdd configuration files.
File(s) affected:
/etc/ypserv.conf
/etc/sysconfig/yppasswdd
